title: VIMuRe v0.1 (latest)
text:
Suppose you want to find out the “true” network of social ties between \(n\) individuals and you query \(m\) “reporters” within this network (where \(m \le n\)) about such ties. These ties could, for instance, represent relationships commonly studied in the social sciences — such as loaning money, giving advice, or sharing food.
Suppose, also, that you ask them questions in both directions: “Who comes to person \(i\) to borrow money?” But also, “Who does person \(i\) go to when borrowing money?” As it is doubtful that the responses given by the reporters will match perfectly, you will almost surely end up with varying perspectives on what should be the same relationship and, so too, varying perspectives on the structure of the overall social network. The question then is, how do you make sense of this data in the face of inconsistent reports and potentially unreliable reporters?
The model in the VIMuRe package is our proposed solution to this problem. It fits a latent network model from multiply-sampled social network data using Bayesian inference, returning a posterior distribution that can later be used to obtain samples or a point-estimate network (e.g., as an igraph object). The package was written in Python and R and is available on GitHub (https://github.com/latentnetworks/vimure).



Input: multiply-sampled social network data as a list of adjacency matrices or igraph objects.
Output: a fitted latent network model that can be used to obtain samples or a point-estimate network (an igraph object) from the posterior distribution of the fitted model.

title: 📦 Installation
text:
VIMuRe is available in both R and Python. The R implementation is a wrapper around the Python implementation. Both packages are in active development and are not yet on CRAN or PyPI. Use the installation instructions below to install the latest development version.

RPython



Step 01: install reticulate with the following command:
install.packages("reticulate")






Why do I need this package?






Our core code is written in python, so we use reticulate to integrate our model in R. This package allows you to use Python within your R session in a seamless, high-performance interoperable way.
reticulate will look for python installed in your computer. If, for some reason, it cannot find it, you may be prompted to download and install miniconda.

Miniconda is the recommended installation method for most users, as it is easier to ensure that the newly installed python is isolated from other python installs you have in your system.
If you initially declined the miniconda installation prompt, you can later manually install miniconda by running reticulate::install_miniconda().







Step 02: install vimure==0.1 with the following command:
require(devtools)
devtools::install_github("latentnetworks/vimure", subdir="src/R", ref="develop")
Step 03: Finally, you must install the Python package as well. This is because the R package is a wrapper around the Python package. To install the Python package, follow the instructions below.
require(vimure)
vimure::install_vimure()
If you are not using RStudio, i.e., you are using R in the terminal, you may need to restart your R session after installing the Python package.
Step 04: To confirm that the installation was successful, run the following command:
library(vimure)
vimure::vm_config()
You should see something like the following:
#> Loaded vimure version
#> Vimure v (...)
#> Python v3.x (...)



Install vimure==0.1 with the following command:
pip install "git+https://github.com/latentnetworks/vimure.git#egg=vimure&subdirectory=src/python/"
This Python package was tested on Python >= 3.6, and it is expected to work fine in all OSes.
Read more about the Python setup for development here.

title: People
text:
Who we are
